Hello crew,

We would like to rebuild the somewhat defunct 'link to us' page, here: http://www.london-2012.co.uk/link/ so that it's actually on london2012.com, and so that it has some refreshed designs.  If I get new pictures separately, could you guys please give me an estimate of the work it would be for you to create the page, but also keep a record (database / spreadsheet / something) of who has used the links (and I suppose how many times they are clicked on).

I also reckon it should be a 'generic content' template, not a generic hub.  There is no need for the picture up at the top!

Let me know your thoughts

Liz

Liz Goulding
Senior New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012
Marking as high.

Hi Liz,

My initial response is 3 days to recreate what you currently have and 5/6 days to make something a bit fancier.

In terms of work it depends largely on how much time we spend on the design of picker ie. do we make it nice and interactive ie. maybe a better selector that lets you select a design and then the size and (more importantly; in terms of cost) the level of tracking / reporting you require.

<snip-depends on reporting requirements>
There is however a architectural issue, which could make certain aspects of this functionality harder to implement on the current live environment, in particular with regards to tracking banner clicks and reporting. The issue lies in the fact that we have 6 live servers with no central/single database (ie. a simple public facing mysql database) in which to track clicks.

Ideally we'd just have one server (even if that was just web06) that was addressed as banners.london2012.com that served up / tracked all banners, that way we could have a single DB of all users and then each time a banner was clicked we updated a row in the database.

In normal circumstances I would simply suggest that we ask BT to setup a new server/instance (banners.london2012.com) and we'd be home and dry; but realise the issues around this / the unlikeliness of this happening. Another approach would be to rent some cloud hosting off a 3rd party (ie. MediaTemple) to just handle the banner serving/tracking, this would solve the issue and be low cost ~$50/month would probably get you all the bandwidth/capacity you needed). But I can understand why ITS may be uneasy about that. Although we do actually already do this (ie. use some cloud hosting from MediaTemple) to handle images arriving from Getty via FTP, this was discussed with Morag/ODA although ITS may not be aware of it; it is also more a backend process/server between Getty and the CMS.
</snipdepends on reporting requirements>

If we don't have a central DB we could still store signups but we won't be able to track clicks on each banner with the same level of granularity and/or create a dedicated reporting interface.

We could track most of the data in Google Analytics by serving the banner in an IFRAME the only thing to be aware of if we took that approach is that the data may not be as readily available on a single page.

So...to recap ;-)

If you happy with us tracking the data in Google Analytics (ie. no single reporting page) then the times at the top still stand.

If you want a single ie. a single reporting page / db then the times/costs aren't widely different, but we would need a server with a mysql DB (or be able to provision on ourselves from say MediaTemple)

Jamie

Hey Jamie,

So, I think what we would like is to keep it Google analytics based, but to create a ‘campaign’ called ‘link to us’ ... so that the link embedded on the images contains a GA tag (i don’t think we need an iFrame for this?) that we can then track it’s click-usage. I believe that would work? I’ve attached the report we are getting at the moment (we don’t currently have any tracking after download at all), so as long as we can continue to collect all the attached data and have a basic understanding of how much traffic is coming through to us from the banners in general, we should be ok.

I think having it be more interactive (choose theme, then size) would be a nice idea. Let me see what the brand team is actually going to produce for us ... it might just be generic. Can you get started without that info.

Does that work? Would that be the 3 day option, or more?

Liz

Hi Liz,

Yes, if all you want to do is track inbound clicks, we could add a parameter to the url so that we know the inbound link came from a banner / the link to us campaign ie. http://www.london2012.com/?campaign=linktous

You could then filter those inbound links by REFERER in Google Analytics to get the domains they came form.

In terms of collecting data, we can capture signups when someone downloads a banner, what we can't do (easily) is automatically correlate signup e-mails to the data in Google Analytics or track the Last Seen and Last URL for a given user, but sounds like your happy to live without this. 

In terms of getting started, it would be good to know the size / range of banners your expecting to use.

3 days would be something fairly basic and akin to what you have now in terms of look/feel and functionality and we'd need to be fairly tight on turnaround/spec to keep it with 3 days, building a nicer interactive picker or if we ended up spending additional time tweaking design/function would probably add another day or two.

In terms of progressing this, if you can get us the sizes of the banners / lets is know if each banner is in different sizes (ie. pick style -> pick size) then we can spend a morning creating a basic mockup and then depending on whether your happy with it either move on to development or spend some more time prototyping it.

Jamie

Any thoughts? something we should get on with?

thanks

Jamie

Damm ZenDesk, doesn't let you do interspersed comments so cant' see what you wrote !

ps. hope your enjoying Turnin (it has to at least be warmer than here)

How mean of it!

GA tracking as you described is fine.
PRobably going to use same banner sizes as we currently have. We prob wont have different styles to start out with, but will going forward. Maybe for a picker we just have people select banner/rectangular/mpu/skyscraper? do you think those are clear?

Go ahead and get started! Once you hit the 3 day 'simple' version let me know, and then we can see if we want to 'upgrade'. :-)
________________________________

It's a more of an either/or rather than an upgrade as we going to have to go down one route or the other.

A flat layout like you have now is going to be quicker to build as we can just reuse the design (although it is a bit ugly as one big page and doesn't even fit properly) so the 3 days is really going to be spent on the backend.

A pickers / new design is going to add on another couple of days as we'll need to do some new design not to mention build it in HTML/CSS/JS and test it cross browser.

In terms of capturing the user data, we are assuming it's OK to just collect a list of users who have signed up? (ie. we're not going to do anything fancy with this data / it won't correlate with clicks or impressions). 

In fact do we really need to force users to go though a register process? given that we aren't going to be using the data we capture in any meaningful way ie. we are correlating it with clicks. If the reasoning is to make people agree to placement rules for the banner image, then would a 'I have read the T&C's checkbox' suffice?

Yes, we’re assuming it’s ok to just have the list of users who signed up. I think we do need to collect all the data, though.

Please do the back-end stuff first, whilst I try and get more info from the brand team to see what we’ll be producing!

Janos I think we can start on this - but do privately Lee track of time spent in zen desk as Liz wants us to approach this in a slightly agile way (or rather she is sure what they want at the front end) so start on the common / backend stuff first and then we can tell her how many days have been used up / what days or budget she then wants to commit to the front end
Can we get an update on this, please?  Have you started?  What's the timeline!
We will be picking this up again as soon as Lars is back from leave. Do you have a due date for this or is it a case of asap?
asap
However, knowing an approximate date would be helpful. We currently pay quarterly for the page, so we want to try and not overpay if possible.
The current quarter ends on Feb 28. I have set the due date as Feb 14.

Hi Liz,

Please see attached PNG, 

We started work on this and decided the current page / form was *so* ugly that it needed a bit of a refresh/rethink ;-) I hope that wasn't too presumptions of us!

Anyway, have a look at the attached PNG, this is what we're proposing to do. It will probably take the total time up by a day or so, but I hope you'll agree it's a vast improvement.

I think my basic 3 day estimate for even migrating what we current have was probably a vast underestimate even without any redesign, esp. if we we need to change images/ tweak etc.

Let us know if your OK with this? I'm expecting this new version will probably take 4 days and maybe 5 with testing / changing images for new versions, tweaks (for example it may be better to be more descriptive with banner sizes?) etc. or you'll prefer a different set of colors and deployment.

thanks

Jamie

btw. as this work is fairly standalone in terms of impact on the rest of the site, I have assumed it can go live without lengthy discussions with ITS/BT. I have therefore only estimated for development / testing on our dev CMS and a single deployment to the live CMS once we're happy with it, with a bit of post launch testing.

Reminder: Liz also wants to make sure that the existing banners do not fail, so we probably need to move them onto the london2012 servers and request for the DNS for london-2012.co.uk to be repointed there.

I don’t want to exceed 5 days – but I think it’s sensible to get it done right.

I would like Zara to feed back on the design when she’s back on Friday. At first glance it’s ok, but she’ll be able to spend more time taking a closer look! I presume she is cced on this ticket?

Zara added to cc list. 

We are happy for feedback on design, but will not expect significant changes. We are continuing to work on this ticket and hope to get it completed in the next few days. We would be much happier if we could make that piece of work a separate ticket.

comments.value:
Hello

We are liking our new mobile site. Currently it is not Android-friendly - can you advise how easily it can be made so? We are looking in particular at the Samsung Galaxy handsets. Grateful for your thoughts!

Morag

Ah, that's a bit of a misnomer I wanted to correct ;-)

The site *is* Android friendly (*)

What it hasn't been is extensively tested on every handset running Android (the issue is the handset/screen size not Android the Operating System). In particular the most common phones used by Samsung staff, whatever that is? We therefore thought it wise not to auto-redirect sites using the Android browser until that testing had been done, in case it upset your Mobile sponsor, once you're happy we can auto-redirect to it.

Just to clarify:

The iPhone is a combined device+OS+software ie. it only has one browser (Safari) and most importantly one screen size (iphone size) so we know it displays correctly on *every* iPhone out there.

Android is an Operating System (like Windows or Linux) it's *not* a device and it therefore doesn't specify a screen size, in fact Android doesn't even guarantee you'll be using a given web browser, although most likely you'll be using the default one, which (as luck would have it) is exactly the same rendering engine as Safari on an iPhone. What this means is that any phone running Android with a screen size similar to the iPhone will render the site exactly as it is rendered on an iPhone.

The issue is not Android vs iPhone OS (ie. the Operating System of the phone) it's that if someone is running Android on a device with the screen size of a postage stamp the site might not display /exactly/ as intended. Maybe it would be more correct to say "The mobile site will work on any device running Android with a screen size similar to the iPhone" (which I expect is 95%+ of the Android market).

In short the site will render perfectly on any Android device with decent sized rectangular screen.

Do let me know if you need *any* clarification here, as I think we probably need to quickly reel in any confusion that may have been caused.

Jamie

(*) 'Android friendly' really only makes sense in terms of Apps and /not/ websites, because an application (as opposed to a website) is dependent on the OS the phone is running. So while you can say "My app (only) runs on Android and/or iPhone" the same doesn't really apply to a website. My guess is there may have been a small amount of confusion here.

Aha! My misunderstanding then.

The key Samsung handset for us is the Galaxy – does that fall into the 95% of handsets with a screen size similar to the iPhone?

Thanks for all the explanation here – very useful!

Would be /really/ shocked if it didn't render properly on a Galaxy.

The thing is we can only redirect on the OS/Browser query string, so if we let though Android based phones though, we let them all though (screen size isn't included). Now this shouldn't be an issue and if you have a phone with a screen the size of a postage stamp I expect your used to seeing sites not rending as expected.

But and this is the important thing, we can't guarantee that the site will look perfect on all phones running the Android OS, it's a bit like we can guarantee that the main www site will look OK on a PC with a 14 monitor.

All that said the site is basic HTML with a some simple Javascript, which should degrade gracefully on almost any mobile browser, so can't imagine it looking too wrong even on a really badly designed phone.

Should we also auto direct Andoid handsets then?

* IMO I think it's probably safe
Yes, go for it!
Marking as high.

Janos,

Can we add in a redirect for the Android UA 

* remember to up ticket time to account for testing on dev (and staging? <-- may nto be possible yet)

anos,

We have just learned that .../games/venues/olympic-village.php and .../indexb.php are receiving a lot of hits and are resolving to page not founds.  This is because /olympic-village has been changed to athletes-village and /indexb is no longer active on the homepage.

I tried to just set up short url redirects to fix this problem - but there are 'invalid characters' and the CMS won't let me.  (screen grab below)

Can you *urgently* please set up redirects for those two pages.  And then less urgently fix the bug in the short url tool?

[cid:image001.png@01CBB1AC.39505B90]

Liz Goulding
Senior New Media Producer
London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games and Paralympic Games
Direct line: +44 (0) 203 2012 297
Switchboard: +44 (0) 203 2012 000
www.london2012.com
www.twitter.com/london2012

Have created redirects for both,

http://www.london2012.com/games/venues/olympic-village.php
http://www.london2012.com/indexb.php

The 'invalid characters' are due to the slash, we have to be *really* restrictive with the short url tool as we generate an Apache server config from it so a / (which has a special meaning in a server config file) could bring down all the servers. So we though better to be safe (and restrictive) than sorry.

Jamie
Please also see #2447. I have just added you to the cc list.
Most important is that you guys were able to fix. Just need to probably add such a thing to the list of things only you can do for any required out of hours support?

Actually K reminded me it's the . not the / (which we now deal with) but basically it's same concern.

Anyway, both urls fixed, which as you say, is the main thing :-)

* Obviously there is a need to create redirect for pages that have moved, but we also don't want the redirect file ending up with 10,000's of redirect rules if we can help it (as each request has to look though it before serving a page) so it may be best to alert us when pages or sections are moved (which should always be done with some care as the url is going to change) and then we can work out the best way to redirect those pages (we may be able to create one rule than catches a whole section for example rather than one rule for each page in that section).

CDATA containers: Take a look at: http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/preview/kierancdata.php (client new2012) it just contains a single "cdata" container. Now, the editor kind-of allows you to amend the contents: http://dev.kitsite.com/kit/pages/edit/kierancdata.php I say "kind-of" because it doesn't actually serialize the contents of the cdata container. (NB I've just amended the java so that it wraps the cdata contents in a 
 tag, to get the whitespace to display. It might be worth removing it, and (if possible) using css instead to display whitespace instead.)

At present if you save it, the cdata contents are ignored (and thus emptied). There is a workaround for replacing them: you can run the following in the console: 

var p = Page.get("kierancdata.php");
p.xml = 
  some arbitrary html make that it's valid html for example,
  escape ampersands thus: &

]]> 
p.update(); 

I think the task is as follows:

 1. Work out whether you need the 
 tag in the page editor.
 
 2. Ensure that - when the page is serialized - any cdata elements are also serialized. Depending on the answer to (1.) you might need to remove the 
 wrapper.
 
Another note: when I say "cdata" I actually mean a (kitsite) container of type "cdata" - rather than an actual  element.

Hope this makes sense!
I think we got this solved and using it on various clients, am I wrong?

I believe so yes.
Venda being the main example.
Marking as solved.

Ticket #1170 "Lee Valley White Water Centre vi..." was closed and merged into this ticket.

Last Comment in #1170: Hi Uzma,
Can I just double-check what led you to believe that the scheduling had not worked?
I ask, because the log files are telling me that videos/2010/lee-valley-white-water-centre.php was indeed published by the scheduler at 10:00:55. Once it is "published" (which should more accurately be known as "queued for publication", it then takes a minute or so for the cms to actually promote it to the live servers. There is then a synchronisation process (which Kitsite has no control over) which can then take up to 5 minutes to push the updates across all of the live servers. The upshot is that - even if scheduling was working perfectly - your page would not have appeared on the live site for up to 5 or 6 minutes (sometimes even longer, at busy times).
The next time you schedule a page for publication could you let us know before you do it please, so that someone can (virtually!) look over your shoulder to see what is going wrong.
Thanks in advance,
Kieran

For "Other dates" (i.e. more than 3 days away) the scheduler currently requires that the user enter the required date in the correct format. If scheduling is going to be done at all frequently, then we would suggest an upgrade to the interface, as follows:

1. Double-check the date format you enter, and display an error if it's incorrect. 
2. Stop the time defaulting to the /current/ time.
3. Allow you to "cancel" a manually entered date, and revert to the pop-down. 
4. Display some instructions (when manually entering a date).

Approximately 1 day in total.

Liz, awaiting your approval.
Go for it.
Reset to high.

Janos, can you take a look at this please?

Basically the scheduler interface (the popup that appears when you select an item and click on the Clock) needs amending as follows:


1. If you select "Other date..." from the popdown, you are allowed to manually enter a date. This needs amending as follows:

 1.1. We (maybe) need a message to appear, indicating that you should enter the date in "yyyy/mm/dd" or "yyyy/mm/dd hh24:mi" format. 
 1.2. We need to double-check (in javascript), when you click on "Done" that the date format meets the above date spec, and display an error msg if it doesn't. It would probably make sense to check for dates in the past, too.
 1.3. If you decide that you /don't/ want to manually specify a date, you need to be able to get back to the original popdown (ask me if you don't know what I mean here).
 1.4. If the date spec includes a time, this needs to be parsed, and sent in the xcall.

I've estimated up to a day for this, but it might take less.

Any questions, give me a shout.

PS "Clear" in the Schedule popup means "Completely clear this item's schedule" - i.e. it performs the xcall - it doesn't just clear the values in the window.

Schedule now is a bit smarter - more comfortable to set an arbitrary date + there are some checks to make sure user sets a valid publication / expiry date. Checked in + deployed to dev for Kieran to have a look.
